docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Dealing With Depression and the Perils of Pregnancy'' (Jan. 13): The symptoms of quitting antidepressants, like frequent crying, do not result from ending an effective treatment but from taking a brain-altering drug.
docs.abstract: Dr David Cohen letter on January 13 article on antidepressants and pregnancy holds that ending antidepressant drug regimen should be gradual to avoid withdrawal symptoms and future problems (S)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''Dealing With Depression and the Perils of Pregnancy'' (Jan. 13): The symptoms of quitting antidepressants, like frequent crying, do not result from ending an effective treatment but from taking a brain-altering drug.

docs.lead_paragraph: Caroline Payne embraces the ethics of America. She works hard and has no patience with those who don't. She has owned a house, pursued an education and deferred to the needs of her child. Yet she can barely pay her bills. Her earnings have hovered in a twilight between poverty and minimal comfort, usually between $8,000 and $12,000 a year. She is the invisible American, unnoticed because she blends in. Like millions at the bottom of the labor force who contribute to the country's prosperity, Caroline's diligence is a camouflage. At the convenience store where she works, customers do not see that she struggles against destitution.

headline.main: A Poor Cousin of the Middle Class

docs.abstract: David K Shipler article profiles Caroline Payne, part of hidden America that consists of millions of people at bottom of labor force who earn low wages and struggle against destitution; many are in search of something better and move from job to job, place to place without anchoring themselves to community and have no support system; Payne, who used to be homeless, earned college diploma, but has been unable to get good paying job, earning only minimum wage or just above it doing menial work; she is continually passed over for promotions, despite agreeable temperament and willingness to work shifts; she is described as having 'face of poverty,' having lost her teeth because she could not afford dentist; her dream to own home seems far out of reach, as she raises mentally retarded daughter, eking out living; photos (L)
docs.snippet: Caroline Payne embraces the ethics of America. She works hard and has no patience with those who don't. She has owned a house, pursued an education and deferred to the needs of her child. Yet she can barely pay her bills. Her earnings have hovered in...

docs.lead_paragraph: SHE'S a fiery horse, ready to explode every 30 seconds, as one rider put it. Star of the show ring, with the horse world's equivalent of a cult following, she is also a very strong business proposition. The horse is Sabrina, an eight-year-old mare who was named Morgan Horse of the Year in 2002 and World Champion in her class the year before. Sabrina, who lives in Katonah, is so game and eager to get down to business (which most of the time is walk, trot and canter both ways around a ring), that it takes two people to hold her for her owner to climb in the saddle.

headline.main: Traits That Owners Are Willing to Pay Dearly For

docs.abstract: Article on Sabria, eight-year-old mare named Morgan Horse of Year in 2002 and 2001 World Champion owned by Clare Simpson of Katonah, NY; Sabrina is one of top 10 most athletic horses in breed that has generated steady stream of inquiries from people wanting to buy her embryos; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Norman and Cathy Wilson have their hands, and their home, full. Each cradles a sleeping baby as they pad around their apartment in Crown Heights, Brooklyn. Mrs. Wilson's daughter Jasmine, 12, sits on the sofa holding another baby to her shoulder. The triplets were born on Dec. 17. It was an uncomfortable pregnancy, with Mrs. Wilson required to be in the hospital for two weeks before the delivery.

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; Births Double Family's Size And Triple Its Challenges

docs.abstract: Anna Bahney The Neediest Cases column discusses struggle of Norman and Cathy Wilson to provide for newly-born triplets; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration's idea of spending $1.5 billion promoting marriage is one of those rather expensive but basically symbolic gestures that presidents like to make in election years. Mr. Bush's advisers may also hope that it will divert social conservatives from pressing for a constitutional amendment banning gay marriages. But as meaningless sops to powerful voting blocs go, this one is particularly cruel. The whole idea of encouraging poor people to get married and stay married through classes and counseling sessions ignores the main reason that stable wedlock is rare in inner cities: the epidemics of joblessness and incarceration that have stripped those communities of what social scientists call ''marriageable'' men. Women in poor neighborhoods may find bitter amusement in the idea that they need the government's encouragement to search for a husband, or that conflict resolution courses are the way to shore up troubled unions between two poor people.
docs.abstract: Editorial contends that Bush administration's idea of spending $1.5 billion promoting marriage is one of those expensive but basically symbolic gestures that presidents like to make in election years; says Bush's advisers may also hope that it will divert social conservatives from pressing for constitutional amendment banning gay marriages

docs.lead_paragraph: Even though Ana Rodriguez complained of abdominal pain and delivered a placenta after being rushed to the hospital, she insisted she had not given birth, the police said. But when Suffolk County police officers went to her home in North Bay Shore on Saturday, they found bags of bloody rags and a dead seven-pound baby boy in a bucket under the kitchen sink, the police said. The baby was born alive on Jan. 8 or 9, and died of asphyxiation, Detective Lt. Jack Fitzpatrick said.

headline.main: Suffolk Mother Is Accused of Killing Newborn

docs.abstract: Ana Rodriguez, mother of three in North Bay Shore, LI, is charged with murdering her newborn fourth baby, which was found in bucket at Rodriguez home, dead from asphyxiation (S)
